DOC.HEAD: Poll Indicates Changes In Views Toward Abortion.
DOC.TEXT: A nationwide poll published Sunday suggests a shift in tolerance toward abortion compared to the results of a similar survey last spring. According to the poll conducted for The Boston Globe and WBZ-TV, 37 percent of the 1,000 registered voters surveyed said they supported legal abortion ``in all circumstances,'' compared to 25 percent nine months ago. Eleven percent said abortion should not be legal in any case, compared to 19 percent in March, according to the Boston Sunday Globe. There was little change over the question whether abortion should be legal ``in certain circumstances.'' Fifty-three percent said ``yes'' in December, compared to 51 percent in March. The random telephone survey by KRC@Communications Research of Cambridge had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent. On the question of whether public funds should be used for abortions for women who cannot afford them, 49 percent of the December sample said the money should be available and 34 percent said it should not be used. In March, 35 percent of those asked said public funds should be available, while 49 percent said the government should not earmark money for abortions. The December poll posed a question that was not asked in March: ``In general, do you think that a woman should or should not be able to obtain an abortion?'' Sixty-eight percent said she should and 25 percent said she should not. The Globe said the December poll sought to assess interest in laws passed in Pennsylvania following the July U.S. Supreme Court ruling that gave states more authority to regulate abortions. Seventy-six percent said they favored for their state the Pennsylvania rule requiring a woman seeking an abortion to be advised by medical workers about fetal development, abortion risks and alternatives and wait 24 hours before the procedure is done. The law was opposed by 16 percent. Sixty-one percent favored the idea of a Pennsylvania law that requires a woman seeking an abortion to tell her husband unless he is not the father, cannot be found, would threaten the woman if told or the pregnancy was caused by rape. It was opposed by 31 percent.
